Articles.Content:
This is just a black skybox speckled with the occasional galaxy, It is perfect for interstellar planet packs as it really accentuates the emptyness of space.

Javascript is disabled. View full album

Download:Dropbox

Download:Hi-Res starry

Edited January 29, 2016 by daniel l.
Modernized, And links fixed.

"Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International Public License"

That is the limit of what you need to have in your post. Have it just hyperlink to the CC page for the rest. Including the whole thing is very spammy and distracting
No pics? No clicks.

No pics? No clicks.

I uploaded a pic for you

i don't get it, is the galaxy skybox the totally black background with that tiny, eeny-weeny spiral galaxy thingy in the top right hand corner? cos i'm with you on the whole "a galaxy within a galaxy is weird" thing, but don't really see what is on offer. if it's a skybox, why not upload a screenshot of the thing from non-map gameplay view, maybe show a kerbal on EVA with your skybox rockin in the background? then we'd know what's up.

btw - not trying to be harsh, just interested in the mod so i wanna now more
Are you sure this isn't "The Universe is almost dead" skybox???

You see in intergalactic space there are no stars in fact you might have to travel 100 miles just to find a single atom.

The only things you'd see in the distance would be other galaxies.

I have made a awesome yet simple skybox to satisfy the starsystems users (Because starsystems makes a galaxy and a galaxy inside a galaxy is awkward )

This is just a black skybox speckled with the occasional galaxy

http://i.imgur.com/cWgAr7J.png

Download:http://www./download/7og82wttlo7t0gw/Daniels_Intergalactic_Skybox.zip

This mod requires texture replacer which is licensed under MIT License

Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International Public License

How do you have so many stars? when i look at the mod there is only 3...

I assure its not, But it is what you would would see if you left our home galaxy,

Its designed to be a backdrop for those who use starsystems.

- - - Updated - - -

Its part of my upcoming pack thats to include this skybox modded starsystems and (Hopefully) A full galactic disc and particle nebulas that you fly inside and experience the true home of kraken

Thats how i feel

Its part of my upcoming pack thats to include this skybox modded starsystems and (Hopefully) A full galactic disc and particle nebulas that you fly inside and experience the true home of kraken

that sounds awesome actually. i wish you success in your endeavour

without having read the other posts, the images look like kerbol left its galaxy 10 million years ago and is now in the void between galaxies. looks not bad but not good either, but a good point to expand i guess. anyways, thanks for your time and dedication
Technically though you wouldn't see this until you left the disk of the galaxy. What you have there is an intergalactic view. An interstellar view would still have all the stars in the night sky.

Yes you are right it is a intergalactic view

I designed it to explain why the universe is so small because here kerbol would be a ejected system or ing the case of star systems mod, a ejected cluster or dwarf galaxy

- - - Updated - - -

Your welcome, I actually made this in gimp in about 30 minutes

I would have expected to see something like the below link if we were ejected or escaped our own galaxy:

http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/spaceimages/details.php?id=PIA12110

A tiny bit of pollution from stars in our own galaxy but:

"This is so narrow, just a few foreground stars in our Milky Way galaxy are visible and are vastly outnumbered by the menagerie of far more distant galaxies"

A lot would not be visible with the naked eye but:

"Though the field is a very small sample of sky area it is considered representative of the typical distribution of galaxies in space because the universe, statistically, looks the same in all directions."
That's intergalactic space as it was billions of years ago, galaxies were much closer to each other back then.

Certainly got me Googling for answers and yes, if you were in intergalactic space with no light and atmospheric pollution, chances are you would see nothing... wow - KSP teaches me stuffs every day

If the galaxy a star was very large and bright, we would possibly still see it from 4,000 light years away - seems like a large number, but considering our own galaxy is 100,000 light years and we only see a fraction of it with the naked eye - then a skybox void of anything of interest is realistic ...and having a few distant galaxies in view is just lucky.

I guess I was too used to seeing skybox eye candy!

Thanks for making me do some interesting research

Edited February 8, 2015 by Deadpan110
lil correction
Your welcome
How is the Star pack coming along?
Right now I,m working on the galaxy ring

This is awesome ! Rep to you m80.

This really reminds that intergalactic medium is...empty.

I think you inspired me into modding.

Technical note : Galaxies inside galaxies are rather called star clusters, and are not akward at all

Thank you for the rep

Star clusters are actually far smaller than galaxies, Sometimes less than a dozen stars, But you make a good point.
How much longer??? Till the pack is done?
Soon, I've got some IRL Things to do, I might have to scrap the galaxy disc and nebula's but i will make you something
